Dear Jim
Once again ny grateful thanks for your much valued expertise.
John.

--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Jim Gilbert" <jggilbert@E...> 
wrote:
> John,
> I don't think that this tsuba could be as early as Nakai 
Tomotsune.  I don't have an attribution for it, but I agree with 
your late Edo period date.  The combination of the naturalistic 
rendering of the grass and the schematic style of the cricket is 
interesting.  The carving of the grass resembles Choshu/Bushu style, 
although of course many others did the same, and the style of the 
cricket is a lot like the sukashi "drawing" style in Akasaka work.
> 
> Jim 
> 
> 
> 
>   Dear colleagues
> 
>   I should be grateful for any pointers that you can offer me 
>   regarding an attribution for the tsuba illustrated in my photo 
album 
>   JPL.  It is of a violet/black shakudo, and was purchased by its 
>   previous owner in 1938.  It depicts, in a delicate openwork, a 
bell 
>   cricket amidst suzuki grasses.  The grass is decorated with gold 
>   taka-zogan dewdrops.
> 
>   I have always thought, by reason of the 'brightness' of its 
>   execution, the lack of any evidence of it ever having been 
mounted, 
>   and sekigane in the nakago-hitsu that appear more decorative 
than 
>   functional, that it was Edo work.
> 
>   During a recent visit to the Bing exhibition, at the Van Gough 
>   Museum in Amsterdam, I saw a very similar guard on loan from the 
>   Museum fur Kunst et Kewerbe in Hamburg - stupidly I omitted to 
>   record its accession number.  This was attributed to Nakai 
Zensuke 
>   Tomotsune I (1669 -1730.  Can I be so wrong in the dating of my 
own 
>   tsuba?
> 
>   With my thanks in advance for any suggestions
>   John L.
> 
> 
> 
> [Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
